Author: ingenium
Content: Just as an update, I have several friends who are medical doctors and have tried kratom. They unanimously approve of kratom for medical as well as recreational uses.

Title: Touching on Apple's Mouseless Future - Is Apple about to kill mouse?

Author: ingenium
Content:
Can you show me that tobacco was used habitually for thousands of years? It wasn't until Europeans started growing plantations of it in the Americas that it was used like this. The native people used it during ceremonial purposes, but this small of usage isn't harmful.

We arrived that these beneficial uses from what others have said and from personal experience. I can testify that one "dose" of kratom is similar in strength to 20-30mg of hydrocodone. There also have been studies showing that the active ingredient is in fact an opiate. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sites/entrez?cmd=Retrieve&db...

As for a doctor's opinion, I have several friends who are medical doctors and have tried kratom. They unanimously approve of kratom for medical as well as recreational uses.

Author: ingenium
Content:
I think it's assumed by this point that a pregnant woman should not take any drug while pregnant. You would have to be an idiot to even think otherwise.

We do know that there are no long term effects, at least not those that the FDA would discover during their test. Kratom has been used for centuries in Southeast Asia. If it was causing serious harmful long-term effects, these people would have figured it out by now.

Author: rms
Content:
>Animal testing on alkaloids from the same species?

Animal testing on alkaloids extracted from the kratom plant, mitragyna speciosa.

Author: nickb
Title: Apple Now Worth more than IBM

Author: ingenium
Content:
>So you are insinuating, that Kratom is an opiate of some kind. As a matter of fact, it's a plant and contains many known and unknown substances.

And you are wrong. It most certainly is. Chemical analysis of kratom shows that it contains 7-hydroxymitragynine, which is in fact an opiate several times stronger than morphine.

Author: ingenium
Content:
>The US DEA says "there is no legitimate medical use for kratom in the U. S." and has placed it on its list of "drugs and chemicals of concern".

This means nothing. Alcohol can also be said to have no medical use. The active ingredient in Kratom however, 7-hydroxymitragynine, is absolutely an opiate and consequently a pain killer. Therefore, it absolutely DOES have medical use.

Author: ingenium
Content: If you are actually into the pharmacology industry, then you would know that most pharmaceuticals are derived from plants, fungi, or other organisms. They simply then add or remove functional groups to tweak them to be a little more effective or patentable. Pharmacology also has developed drugs to let you keep an erection for 4 hours and to put you in a better mood. So I fail to see the difference. Furthermore, how many drugs have been granted FDA approval only to later be found to be dangerous? FDA approval really doesn't mean that much...what DOES is if something has been commonly used for centuries by a particular culture; if it was "poisoning people", they wouldn't have continued using it.

Author: daniel-cussen
Content: This looks like an excellent time to split hairs and point out that snake-oil is actually good medicine, despite its metaphorical usage. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snake_oil

Author: inklesspen
Content: Overdose is not the only factor to consider. What about cancer? Birth defects if a pregnant woman uses it? Neurological effects? These are the things that a scientific drug test is designed to discover. Without a properly designed scientific test, you cannot claim there are no harmful long-term effects. You simply don't know.

Author: rms
Content: Thanks, great post, look forward to part 2.

Author: brianmckenzie
Content:
Make good friends. Hang around smart intelligent educated 'moral' people. Form networks - these networks matter to get jobs, etc. Remember, 90% of the good things you get in life (jobs, stock tips, hot dates) will be informally, via your network of friends/colleagues.

On my first day of high school, my dad gave me a priceless piece of advice: Don't be friends with people just because they're available and easy to be friends with. Seek out the people worth befriending, and become their friend no matter how hard it is.

I didn't really understand him at the time, but 15 years later it strikes me as one of the most valuable things anyone has ever told me.

Author: inklesspen
Content: There certainly is something dishonest about saying "I am not selling product X for purpose Y" when every time we see him promote product X, he is discussing it in the context of purpose Y.

Author: ingenium
Content:
I've done kratom, as I'm selling it with rms. I've also taken prescription pain killers, and I can assure you that it is definitely the real thing.

A web startup is not for everyone. The problem with web 2.0 is that most of the time, there simply is no business model. Selling kratom does have a clear business model. I fail to see what the difference is between selling kratom and selling something as a "health supplement". Neither have been FDA tested or verified. Yet people are perfectly fine with selling and buying supplements which are usually just placebos.

Author: greendestiny
Content:
You stand by your claims? So what. Animal testing on alkaloids from the same species? So what! You feel it would hold up to scientific testing? What on earth have you feelings got to do with scientific testing.

You're selling a product on the basis of it not being consumed by humans knowing full well that it is. Your claim that your customers don't get any information from you is at odds with the advocacy for kratom you've displayed on this forum for one.

Author: rms
Content: Thanks for that post. Can you edit the numbered statement to get rid of the leading space? This triggered the code mode which is causing horizontal scrolling on my screen.

Author: inklesspen
Content:
"Would kratom be ok if I was a pharmaceutical company and I told you that Kratom could help you lose weight, be happy, and be more productive? It is an incredibly viable alternative to oxycontin for pain management. How about as an alternative to SSRIs/Benzodiazepines as an anti-depressant/anti-anxiety medication? How about that kratom can seriously enhance productivity, more so than caffeine but less so than amphetamine and with fewer side effects than either?

Disclaimer: Kratom can cause nausea, itching, and constipation, just like other opiates. Like other opiates, it can seriously potentiate other pharmaceuticals and you should ask your doctor if kratom is right for you."

If you don't recognize where that came from, just look up at the top of the thread. I'd like you to point out the part where he admits he has no scientific evidence for any of his claims.

Moreover, if you're making medical claims for which you have no scientific evidence, you have no way of knowing if you're making misleading claims or not. He has a responsibility to his customers, and he is not fulfilling it.

Author: ingenium
Content:
The DEA never made any claims that it WAS harmful. They provide no evidence for this. All they claim is that it has "no medical uses" and use this to justify making it a controlled/illegal substance.

Alcohol, however, is the worst drug you could do other than methamphetamine. It is quite literally a poison. It is impossible to overdose on THC. How many other drugs, legal or illegal, can the same be said for?

Author: curi
Content: It seems blatantly obvious that rms has a positive opinion of kratom, but that he's selling it in the style of "use at your own risk and discretion". There's nothing dishonest about that.

Author: curi
Content: There is no fraud involved in selling Kratom, nor any force. rms is not making misleading medical claims, he's been clear it hasn't passed rigorous scientific standards.

Author: brianmckenzie
Content:
So, the decisions for this YC funding cycle will be out in a few weeks. This means that a bunch of Hacker News readers will be moving to the Bay Area soon.

Since I already live here, I'm putting together a brief guide to bootstrapping in SF. It's not as hard as you'd think, but this is a very different kind of city and there are some things to consider before you arrive. Hopefully this will help!

Author: brianmckenzie
Title: Moving to San Francisco? Some Tips.

Author: falsestprophet
Content:
"What do you think pharmacists and Chinese herbalists are?"

  1. I think pharmacists have pretty easy, lucrative jobs. Good for them. I also know a lot of student pharmacists. Some of them are very cute. Good for them.
  2. I think Chinese herbalists are naive and, in general, smell strange.
I hope, maybe, to be a pharmacologist one day. Our work is somewhat different than yours. You get people high. We kill the plague.

I am trying not to dislike you. But you said, "I am sure though that the effectiveness would be demonstrated." Really you are sure? You are sure you aren't poisoning people? I am not.

Author: inklesspen
Content:
You are a liar if you claim you are selling it "not for human consumption". The whole controversy that lead you to post this thread came about because you were advocating kratom as a substance for "chemically enhanced social interaction", saying it is "well suited to truly enhanced discussion".

While your website claims it is not for human consumption, this is a dodge that likely won't help you very much if you ever get in trouble with the law. You know full well that people are buying it for use as a drug, and if you have been promoting it as such here, you likely have been promoting it as such elsewhere.

As to your claims about the DEA, please provide scientifically verifiable evidence that the DEA is wrong in this case. Studies have been made and analyzed about THC; I'm not aware of any such studies of kratom.
